page.title: 10Trowlesworthy local history2
page.content: PLACE NAMES The name "warren" occurs five times and "burrow" once. This is a reminder that the area uaed to have a thriving rabbit_breeding industry,which grew up with the enlargement of the Dockyard in the time of William IV and continued well into this century. In the warrens the rabbits lived in characteristic pillow monds,because the wet,peaty ground was unsuitable for their burrows. In Brisworthy burrows the tinners' spoil heaps were used in the same way. The suffix "_worthy" means farmstead and is included in the names of both the farms. The large Bronze Age stone circle or ring gives its name to "Ringmoor". "HenTor" is so called because of its resemblance of one of its boulders to a sitting hen.
